lines.text:
[looking at Hendrik's painting of her]
It's not like I am at all. But it's who I'd like to be.
[looking at Hendrik]
Why am I not like that?

Perhaps you haven't found what you want yet, perhaps you're unfulfilled. Perhaps you don't even know what you want, perhaps you're discontented. Discontentment often finds vent through malice and destruction.

[suddenly angry]
Malice and destruction, is that what you think? Well perhaps I can find something here to destroy.
I'm quite certain you will.
Your painting of me perhaps. Would you like me to destroy your painting?

[calmly]
If it would help to quiet your soul.
How long have you worked on it?

[still perfectly calm]
Does it matter?

[picks up a palette knife]
Shall I do it then?
By all means.
[Pandora uses the knife to scratch out the face of the painted Pandora. Hendrik watches then calmly and wordlessly comes over to inspect the damage]
[stunned by his calmness]
Aren't you angry?
I was angry once before. I can never be angry again.

[pause, then quietly]
You've made me feel quite ashamed of myself. It's a new emotion, I'm not sure I like it.
To understand one human soul is like trying to empty the sea with a cup.

If I say that I have two samples of handwriting three centuries apart, everyone will say "Poor Geoffrey's lost his wits". Because we live in a time that has no faith in legends, we live in a time that has no faith.
I am Pandora Reynolds of Indianapolis and points East.
No one has the right to read Dutch. Unless of course you are Dutch, like Hendrik.
I pity you not MY doom, but GOD'S!

[after saying there is no such thing as a faithful woman]
If this be folly, and upon me proved, then let the Divinity which I reject, make what sport He will of my immortal soul!

[about Pandora and the Dutchman]
I know now that they were in love. But I have a feeling that they never spoke of it.
The measure of love is what one is willing to give up for it.
